title: How to Knit a Skinny Headband

steps.headline: Choose your yarn and needles.
steps.description: As a general rule of thumb, the needles should be close to the thickness of the yarn. But if you want easy lacy holes in the headband, use large needles with thin yarn. Choose a stiffer yarn if you're working with an intricate pattern that you do not want to stretch out; cotton yarn works well.

steps.headline: Cast on two to five stitches.
steps.description: The fewer stitches, the skinnier the headband; the more stitches, the thicker. Leave approximately 3-4 inches (7.5cm-10cm) of tail yarn.

steps.headline: Work in i-cord for about seven inches (17cm) or when the cord reaches from the nape of your head to the back of your ear.
steps.description: (You also want a little extra in case you are knitting this for someone else.) If you like the i-cord, you can make the whole headband in this fashion, but for this article we will assume you're going on. See How to knit an i-cord to learn how.

steps.headline: Begin to turn the work at the end of each row, and start your increases.
steps.description: If you began with three stitches, knit the first stitch, knit the front and the back of the second stitch, and knit the third stitch. Then purl the wrong side of the headband. Continue to increase in the middle of the stitches and knit the outside stitches, while purling on the other side. The more times your increase in one row, the faster the headband will grow in width. Increase to anywhere between six to ten stitches. See How to knit increases for more details.

steps.headline: Begin your stitch pattern.
Repeat your stitch pattern until it measures from one ear lobe to the other across the top of your head.
steps.description: Remember to stretch the yarn while fitting.

steps.headline: Decrease until you have the correct number of stitches for your i-cord.
steps.description: For example if you had eight stitches, knit one, knit two together, knit one, knit two together, knit one, knit two together. Purl the wrong side and continue in a similar fashion until you have for example, three stitches left. See Knit Decreases to learn how.

steps.headline: Knit the i-cord until it measures a little longer than the distance from behind your other ear to the nape of your neck.
Bind off and break the yarn.
steps.description: Leave approximately 3-4 inches (7.5cm to 10cm) of tail yarn on this end as well.

steps.headline: Use a darning needle to thread the end of the tail yarn into the i-cord from its end.
steps.description: Pull it out some distance along the i-cord, pull it so it's very taunt and snip it. Then pull at the i-cord so that the yarn end shrinks into the i-cord. Repeat this at the other end.

steps.headline: Wear your fabulous headband!
steps.description: Wrap it around your head, making sure the right side is facing outwards, and tie the i-cords together at the nape of your neck in a square knot.
